newsitem.title: USA: MGM Interactive sells show to Microsoft Network.
newsitem.headline: MGM Interactive sells show to Microsoft Network.

text.p: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. on Wednesday became one of the first major Hollywood studios to produce a show for the Internet, announcing it would provide a "rock 'n' roll murder mystery" for the Microsoft Network online service.

The show, titled "Paul Is Dead," will be launched on the Microsoft Network (MSN) later this year, MGM Interactive, MGM's computer game unit, said in a statement. MGM Interactive did not provide further details on the show's content.
Of the major studios, only Disney Co.'s Disney Interactive unit has pushed the entertainment envelope by producing content for the Net.
MSN is a division of Redmond, Wash.-based software giant Microsoft Corp.

"MSN is helping to establish the Internet as a mass-market entertainment vehicle where viewer interaction and online communities bring entertainment to new heights," said MGM Interactive General Manager Ron Frankel.
MGM Interactive has five other Net-based shows being developed. Previously, it had produced only CD-ROM and other computer and video games, such as "The Ultimate James Bond, an Interactive Dossier."
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is co-owned by billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda Corp. and Australian media company Seven Network Ltd.
Microsoft's stock fell $3.81 to $130.375 on the New York Stock Exchange in late trading.
